channel.title: Ruffled feathers: The Dakota Sioux
channel.description:
A documentary series about the history, culture and contemporary problems of the Sioux, a Native American tribe.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Life on and off the reservation
item.description: This program tells stories of Sioux life on and off the reservation.
item.dc:creator: University of South Dakota
item.dc:subject: Dakota Indians--History.

item.title: Sioux legal systems
item.description: This program focuses on elements of Sioux legal systems.
item.dc:creator: University of South Dakota
item.dc:subject: Dakota Indians--Legal status, laws, etc.

item.title: The Sioux philosophy
item.description: The carefully structured relationships within the tribe give the Sioux a much different set of values from those found in the society into which they assimilate.
item.dc:creator: University of South Dakota
item.dc:subject: Dakota Indians--History.

item.title: The economics of being Indian
item.description: Per capita income, job opportunity, work skills, and prejudice determine the environment that the average Sioux must exist in.
item.dc:creator: University of South Dakota
item.dc:subject: Dakota Indians--Economic conditions.

item.title: Educational trends among the Sioux
item.description: Evolution of the Sioux educational process and implications of existing system are discussed.
item.dc:creator: University of South Dakota
item.dc:subject: Dakota Indians--Education.

item.title: Tourism and Sioux economic development
item.description: This program focuses on tourism and Sioux economic development.
item.dc:creator: University of South Dakota
item.dc:subject: Dakota Indians--Economic conditions.

item.title: Elements of Sioux art
item.description: This program explores elements of Sioux art. Nationally noted Indian artist Oscar Howe and other midwestern Indian artists discuss the evolution of Indian art.
item.dc:creator: University of South Dakota
item.dc:subject: Dakota art

item.title: Legendary Sioux history
item.description: This program explores some legends and folklore in Sioux Indian history.
item.dc:creator: Diamond, Arlen
item.dc:subject: Dakota Indians--History.

item.title: The Indian in college
item.description: Social adaptability, financial problems, and background are just a few of the factors which determine the success or failure of the Native American in college.
item.dc:creator: University of South Dakota
item.dc:subject: Dakota Indians--Education.

item.title: ICAP: A key to the future?
item.description: The Indian Community Action Project aids the Sioux Indian in many ways. This program looks at those ways.
item.dc:creator: University of South Dakota
item.dc:subject: Dakota Indians--History.

item.title: Sioux dances and music
item.description: This program focuses on Sioux dances and music. It features Edgar Red Cloud, fourth generation grandson of Chief Red Cloud, singing traditional Sioux songs. The music was recorded at the 1966 Oglala Sioux Sun Dance Pow Wow.
item.dc:creator: University of South Dakota
item.dc:subject: Dakota dance

item.title: Contemporary Sioux history
item.description: This program focuses on contemporary Sioux history. The movement of the Sioux peoples is traced. Other issues covered include Indian treaties; Indian wars; impact of non-Indian settlement; and the impact of the reservation system.
item.dc:creator: Diamond, Arlen
item.dc:subject: Dakota Indians--History.

item.title: Patterns of Sioux religion
item.description: From traditional culture has arisen a combination of old and new: Indian and Christian. The Native Church of America, which uses peyote, is also prominent.
item.dc:creator: University of South Dakota
item.dc:subject: Dakota Indians--Rites and ceremonies.
